Mar 31 2008	More Than Just a Name	Don't let the name fool you, this is unlike any Days Inn you've probably ever seen. We booked this trip with Gate 1 Travel and were very pleased. The hotel is brand new, just opened in October 2007.The rooms have very modern furniture, a flat screen TV, free high speed internet, huge shower, and are very clean. The location is perfect; just a few minute walk to the Forbidden City and Tienanmen Square. There is a huge shopping center just a couple blocks away and several authentic Chinese restaurants literally steps away. We felt totally safe at all hours too.We had a hot American style buffet breakfast every day including an omelet station. What Days Inn back in the States has an omelet station? There was always someone who spoke English on the staff and they were super helpful with any request we had. Honestly, this hotel was nicer than many Hilton's I've stayed in. I would definitely recommend it for just about any visitor. My only gripe is that the bed was pretty hard. It didn't seem to matter too much after a long day of walking to see the sights but as far as softness goes, the bed did bear a similarity to the carpeted floor. Other tips if you choose to stay here:We did the Great Wall tour offered by the hotel. You might want to plan a different one, or just pay a cab to take you. There were two unnecessary stops to see "tours" of "factories" that make jade and pottery. This was nothing more than forced shopping excursions which ultimately limited the time at the Great Wall.Since the hotel is new, most cab drivers don't know where it is. The hotel will give you a card, but that won't help much. Have the staff write the major cross streets for you on the card and cab drivers can find it much easier.

Mar 26 2008	Nice place... Nice people	This is a great bargain. Yes, the rooms are a little small and take some hangars with you but it was clean, quiet and comfortable. Save money on travelers checks.. you'll have to go to the bank to cash them and there's an ATM in the hotel lobby that gives you all the Yuang you need at a competitive rate. The tour people at the desk are wonderful.. especially Sabrina! I suggest, however, that you get a cab to and from the hotel.. it should run you around Y100. If you book the hotels car it is Y150.I highly recommend the Li Family Restaurant but make your reservations at least three weeks ahead. It's called Li Jai Cai at 11 Yangang, deshengmen wai hutong, phone [--]. Dinner will run about Y200 ($28 u.s.) or Y300. It is wonderful.Oh, and if you want olympic baseball hats to take home you should be able to get them easily for $1 each or Y70.

Mar 25 2008 	Problem Solving Staff In A Bargain Of A Hotel	This hotel had it problems but it is definitely a bargain. The rooms are a little worn and our first room reaked of sewage. The friendly staff moved us to another room as quickly as they could. The front desk is very helpful with almost everything. Beds are more like boxsprings than mattresses but I heard many rooms in Beijing are like this. If you get a taxi chances are they won't know where the hotel is, but just have them drop you off around the corner at the Grand Beijing Hotel. The Forbidden City and Tianeman Square are within easy walking distance and a metro stop is also close. I saw rates as low as $40 a night on some web sites, making this a can't miss deal. The hotel was booked to capacity so book early. This is a solid two and a half star hotel maybe even a three in my book(on a scale of four). This hotel is by no means luxurious or flashy. It's a good decent hotel in a fantastic location. May not be for the finicky or hard to please traveler. My friend was in a deluxe room which was definitley a little nicer than mine. I was extremely pleased with the hotel and bang for buck.

Mar 24 2008 	Great little hotel!	Location: excellent- 5 minute walk to the Forbidden City, the major shopping district, and a subway station. Always easy to hail a cab as well, even if the front desk wants to persuade you to 'book a car' through them- don't bother.Room: Being a new hotel, the rooms are in good shape. The beds are typically Chinese- very hard! Free internet was a good thing here, too. We had no issues with hearing other rooms. There's an in-room safe, and the closet is very small. The only complaint is that the hotel smelled of chemicals- like carpet glue or something, which I imagine is because the hotel is so new. Opening the room window was enough to solve this issue, though. It was also nice to get free water in the room and the bathroom products were more than I got at a lot of other hotels in China.Service: We had no issues with service- the English at the front desk is quite good. The same cannot be said of housekeeping, but we always managed to creatively communicate. The desk staff were also helpful in writing our destinations in Chinese for our cab drivers- I would highly reccomend this to anyone traveling by cab. It was nearly impossible to instruct the drivers otherwise.I would definitely recommend staying in this hotel. I also booked through the Days Inn site and managed to get a really good rate online.

Mar 23 2008 	Best Choice for Beijing	There are several options for Beijing hotels - a giant Marriott etc, a Chinese hotel, a hutong courtyard-style place.We loved the idea of a hutong hotel, but worried about picking a bad one (the ones widely recommended seem to be permanently booked). Big hotels don't appeal to us and are too expensive if well-located.We settled on the Days Inn Forbidden City and we can't say enough good things about it. The price was great ($75 for a queen bed - didn't see the cheaper basement rooms, but really, don't do that to yourself) and the location can't be beat. This hotel is literally a 3 minute walk to Tiananmen Square and the Forbidden City entrance. It is 2 minutes walk to the Line 1 subway (Tiananmen East stop), and a 10 minute walk to the Wangfujing shopping street.Cabbies had no trouble finding it (the hotel will give you a card with directions in Chinese).Rooms were a bit small and had no bar fridge, but had 2-person shower, snazzy vessel sink, flat TVs with CNN (occasionally censored ;)), AC, free coffee and tea and 2 bottles of water a day.The beds were firm in a good way, and the linens immaculate.The hotel feels about 2 years old at most, the desk staff speak english, there is a currency changing machine and internet access in the lobby, the cafe has a great-but-pricey Western breakfast (we love Chinese food, but it's nice to have a familiar breakfast to start the day, no?)They arranged a car to take us to the airport for a decent price too.Book via the main Days Inn website, not hotels.com etc, as there is no savings. Note, though, that the maps on the website and most website like Venere are really wrong. It is north of the main East-west street with the subway line 1 under it (can't remember the name), just off Nanwanzey, to the east of Forbidden City. The maps show it as west, near a small lake, which is wrong. It is just around the corner from Raffles.

Mar 15 2008	Location! Location! Location!	We stayed in a deluxe room from 10-15 March. We found the room to be very comfortable (though the bathroom had a smell). The staff were very accomodating- provided us with a powerboard wthat could be used for our DVD player, phone chargers etc; turned off the radiator which was making the room uncomfortably warm; extra towels/hangers ... For the price we paid (428RMB/nite), it was a real steal. There is a fabulous machine in the lobby that converted major currencies into RMB, so you don't worry about not having enough RMB. The rate I got for exchanging USD to RMB was current and very reasonable.

Mar 10 2008 	Good Feel	I have stayed in a lot of Days Inn in the States so I felt as it was my first trip to China i would stay somewhere familiar, it turned out to be a good decision I found the Inn to be modern and the rooms clean and tidy , the only small complaint was the bed was a bit on the hard side, also no fridge in the room, mind you with -10 outside placing food etc on the window sill did the job.The restaurant was good and the buffet breakfast had a good variety with bacon , chicken sausages, egg station , toast and muffins etc along with the standard Chinese food , the prices were good $10NZD, also you could buy filled bread rolls and sandwiches for $2.50NZD.Most of the reception staff spoke reasonable english and were happy to assit where ever possible.I had all of my dinners at a small local diner about 2 minutes walk away , it had a lot of locals eating there, the menu had photo,s of the meals and the waitress spoke a little english, had a plate of Pork ribs, plate of pork strips and peppers , bowl of Hot and Sour soup , 4 bottles of beer (500 ml) with a friend cost $14.00 NZD.Even though I had no time for sightseeing , the people I spoke to who were staying there said it was close to most of the major places to visit.All in all a very good visit and I will certainly stay there again.

Mar 4 2008 	Comfortable Stay!	This hotel is a very basic hotel, as any Days Inn hotel. It is a very central hotel to visit the Forbidden City and Tiananmen Square and Wangfujing street and its surroundings. The rooms are very small and almost no closet space. I actually thought there wasn't any till I moved the sliding door. The bed is very comfortable and the sheets are high quality. It serves great as a base hotel to get around the city. There were stores around to pick up some drinks and snacks. I only had the breakfast once at the cafe and didn't think it was worth the money. We got down there a little late, that is why there was not much choices left. The rooms I think need a small refrigerator, I have never stayed at any hotel where there was not one available for use. I had to keeps my drinks outside of my window in order to keep it cold. The front desk spoke english very well and answered any questions that I had. The bathroom are an adequate size in my opinion. I know that some said there are small, but they have a sink, shower and toilet what else do you need. Also, the heating system worked very well. The room stayed very warm. I actually had to close the radiators a couple of times because it would get to warm. This has nothing to do with the hotel, but be aware of the first store that is close to the hotel. The store is the first one that you encounter once you exit the hotel and get the street and make a left. They overcharged us twice for drinks and some snacks til we realized he was overcharging us by a lot. The average prices for any drink should be between 3-5 bucks. I stopped going there and walked across the street to the other store and bought stuff there. This store has their drinks on there window display.

Feb 25 2008 	Great little motel	Great little hotel the size of an Aussie motel. Quite clean though the bathrooms seemed a bit worn. Which was weird as the hotel is relatively new. At least one staff member will speak English and as female staying on my own I always felt safe. Small restaurant, make a decent coffee. The breakfasts are basic but filling and offer a mix of traditional chinese foods and western produce, Loved the dumplings. Location wise it is a 10 minute walk to the forbidden city and tianmen sq. It is also only a 10 minute walk to one of the large shopping malls and some still standing hutongs. The hotel provides address cards so there was never a problem catching a cab to and from the hotel unless of course the cab tried to not use the metre. Which by the way is illegal.It is a basic but clean hotel and if that is your expectation you won't be disappointed. The only area it could benefit in is in teaching more of the staff some english particularly as the olympics are just around the corner. And a small fridge in the room wouldn't go astray.

Feb 12 2008 	Very enjoyable stay	We have just returned from Beijing where we took ourselves and my mother to see the Great Wall of China. We visited over the Chinese New Year and decided to stay here based on value and its central location.The only negative point to make is in actually finding the hotel - Taxi drivers simply do not know it exists and even with the card given by the hotel difficulties still arise. By way of advice, I would suggest guests take a tourist map so they can clearly direct the driver.Aside from this, our stay was excellent. The rooms were faultless, warm and welcoming with temperatures reaching -10 degrees Celsius outside. Breakfast was perfectly good with a choice of eggs and a buffet of fruit and bacon, dim sum etc. The hotel bar was one of the cheapest places for a beer that we could find and the service always friendly although no real ambience. The staff were very helpful to the point that they even stood out in the cold to hail us a taxi on two occasions and even walked to the supermarket to fetch us a few beers when we arrived at 1am on New Years morning as it was too late to go out and the hotel bar had closed.Staff always greeted us with a smile and booked us a tour to the great wall which was excellent and recommended, although this may change with the seasons - There was just the three of us and one other in the minibus which was perfect.The front desk did come close to being pushy on a few occasions with tours and cars around town where commission was clearly at stake which is frustrating but not unusual.All in all a great 1st time visit to Beijing made better by a comfortable place to stay in a location that allowed us to see things quickly in the bitter cold before retreating to the warmth of our rooms. If visiting Beijing again, we would stay here without question and would recommend to others.

Jan 29 2008	Excellent hotel perfect location	We stayed at Days Inn Forbidden City from 28th December 07 to 4th January 08. The Hotel should be rated better than 3* It's still has a brand new feel, exceptionally clean and provides good service. The breakfast buffet was very good with a good variety of cereals, cakes, fried vegetables, etc. The rooms are cosy, not large with nice and clean bathroom, LCD TV and huge double beds.The staff is very friendly and just can't do enough for you but they still need to get some experience as they all seem new to their jobs. Their language skills need some improvement too.The Hotel is at an exceptionally perfect location. Both Tiananmen Square and Forbidden City are 3-5 minutes walk away so is a busy shopping street with a huge mall with various international restaurants if you get tired of Chinese food.If I returned to Beijing at any time I would definitely book this hotel again.

Jan 6 2008	Great hotel and fab location	We really enjoyed our stay in this new hotel in December 2007. Its location is ideal for Tian'anmen Sq and the Forbidden City- possibly the closest hotel and a short walk from shopping zone and metro and taxi ride from pearl market,west train station and summer palace and was probably the best value hotel during our trip.Our room was bright,modern, simple, elegant and spotless with the most comfortable bed and best shower (separate cubicle and powerful shower unlike other hotels) we had during our tour. It was also quiet as the hotel is set around a courtyard set back from the street. The staff (especially Ricky Gao) were unfailingly polite, pleasant and helpful despite being very busy at times. They will arrange tours and trips but to save money I used lonely planet and they were very obliging in helping me to organise this by telephoning taxis,theatres etc and translating. They also suggested to us that other guests/fellow budget travellers were planning a trip to jinshanling so we might save more money in a people carrier taxi so we had great company, fun and an affordable trip to the more distant section of the Great Wall.The breakfast and room service are charged separately-annoying but this is the norm in China and the breakfast was very good. The hotel restaurant is good but so too is the independent restaurant across the courtyard. It doesn't have the menu in english (yet) but dont be put off I picked by pointing at pics and the food was delicious -way better than the well known and much more expensive restaurants nearby.

Dec 20 2007 	Value for money	The room is adequately small and clean. The heater in the room is warm and comfortable in the cold weather, even the bathroom felt warm as there was a heater in the bathroom too. The deluxe room view on the 3rd floor was beautiful especially when it snowed on one of the mornings. The location of the hotel is extremely convenient - walking distance to the major attractions in the city. The room service of the hotel is quite efficient, as we had called up to request for adaptors for our handphone charges.We are very satisfied with our stay and will definitely come back to this hotel is we visit Beijing again.

Dec 16 2007 	A Nice Small Hotel	Stayed 4 nights in this newly opened hotel.The street name on the map from the hotel website is not correct. Most cab drivers dont know how to go to this place. Must tell the drivers that the hotel is at the back of BeijingHotel. Then look for the small yellow sign. Location of the hotelis good. 10 minutes walk to Grand Hyatt where there is a elegant shopping mall including supermarket "Ole".Since the main entrance is inside an alley, need to walk to themain street to catch a cab (the walk is less than 1 minute). Or youmay ask hotel staffs to get you a cab.Front desk staffs speak good English and very freindly andhelpful.Room has basically everything except there is no mini fridge.Buffet breakfast does not have a lot of variety but it is OK for afew days stay. Like mist hotels in the big cities in China, two bottles of water provided each day free of charge.Will return to this hotel unless they are not doing the rapair andmaintenance work properly

Dec 5 2007 	Fantastic Cosy Little Hotel	We searched nearly all the hotels in DongCheng before deciding on Days Inn Forbidden City. The hotel is actually on the East side of Forbidden City rather than west side which is exactly what we want. Most locals are not aware that there is this new hotel just next to Forbidden city. It is literally 5 minutes walk to the main entrance of Forbidden city and 5 minutes walk to Wanfujian Street. The hotel staff are really friendly and helpful. Let's assure that they know all the places in Beijing. If you let them know that you really want to try out what locals eat or where they normally go for shopping, they will have more suggestions for you. This is exactly what we are looking for within our budget and get a good feel of what seiheyuan is all about. Mind you, this place have lots of history to offer. We also wanted a cosy, nice, little hotel rather than the international ones, which are too classy and overrated. For the price of US$54, you get very good deluxe room with a good view on the courtyard. Check out [--] or [--] for fantastic offer. also, check on periodic basis and you will fine nice surprises on the rate. The rooms are very well equiped and spacious for 3 star hotel. The bed feel hard, but you just need that after one whole day of walking. The toilets in each room are equiped with the necessities such as shower cap, toothbrush, shampoo, body lotion and the towels are really clean. The hotel lobby also have an ATM machine that allow you to change your foreign currencies although they only accept USD, Euro and Japan currency. So, keep some USD or Euro in case you need it urgently and it works 24 hours instead of you brining your passport out to the bank to change. If you did not book a taxi in advance for a night ride to airport, not to worry. Just get help from the hotel staff who are willing to stand by the roadside to flag a taxi for you even through it is below 0 degree and windy. If you are looking for a cosy and affordable hotel that is close to all the places that you want to visit in Beijing, Days Inn is definitely the best choice. The subway is just around the corner.We have a terrific time staying at Days Inn!!!

Nov 17 2007 	good room helpful staff	We booked a deluxe room for 5 nights at Days Inn Forbidden City. The staff was very friendly and helpful -- they wrote down directions to various tourist sites, arranged taxi to the airport and made good suggestions for food and shows. The room was very clean and nicely furnished. We asked for a non smoking room and was given a room on the non smoking floor. There was an in room safe, hair dryer and heater/AC. 2 bottles of water were provided every morning. We would definately stay there again.

Nov 15 2007 	good location but bad management	The hotel is situated at a very good location. If it's the first time to Beijing, that's an excellent location. Although this hotel claimed under USA company's management, you will realise it's not true. The management style is very chinese and local. This hotel is new but you could see that they are not well managed. The room is small and not very clean. The view of the room is different and most of them are not very good. The breakfast was not good. You can just have a coffee and some bread. For budget travel, this hotel is acceptable.

Nov 13 2007 	Good 3 star hotel	First and foremost, this hotel advertise itself as a 3 star hotel, which I think is very correct description. In fact, for this price range, this is as good as gets in Beijing. Location is fantastic. Within walking distance to the Forbidden City, Tiananment Sq, the Wangfujin shopping district, The Exquisite Park, and to 2 subway stations. If you stay at Days Inn, your Beijing sightseeing literally start at your doorstep. Although it is a cheapos, Days Inn share the same neighbourhood with some really fancy hotels such as The Raffles and The Grand Hotel, so that does speaks something about the hotel location. Room is small but nicely done in comtemporary, IKEA-ish style, and the cheapest room is indeed a semi-basement, meaning you only have a tiny window to allow daylight to come in. If this is an issue, upgrade to a higher category (or you can ask nicely to the receptionist - I got my upgrade for free:)Staff speaks good English, with varying degree of course, but nonetheless enough to get things done - Not a profound problem in the likes Hiltons or Sheratons, but a mini-disaster in smaller, Chinese-owned hotel that are usuallu rated similar to the Days Inn.Overall, I had a satisfying stay at Days Inn Forbidden City. In future visit, even if I have a stretched budget, I will definitely stay at this hotel again.

Nov 10 2007 	good 	Good - great location, new, clean, modern bathroom, flat screen tv, coffee maker in room, nice linens, friendly manager, close to subway, close to Forbidden City, near nice park, small/ low rise building.Bad - no refrigerator, small room, no kleenex, no ice machine, only 4 hangers in tiny closet, little drawer space, only one chair, some rooms in basement!Standard rooms are good value for a couple of nights. Aug 13 2009	Great hotel	Stayed here as part of a Jules Verne tour of China. Of all the hotels we stayed in this was our favourite. Very elegant hotel with huge rooms. Beds large and very comfortable. There was free internet access in the rooms. The restaurant buffet was excellent and catered for all tastes . It was very good value with dinner for around 8 , breakfast also great with lots of Asian dishes along with the usual bacon eggs etc.

Dec 23 2008 	Very nice stay	The hotel stay was very good, breakfast was plentiful and had anything you could desire.Pros: * Hotel facilities * Room size * Breakfast * LocationShortcomings: * Internet access in the room doesn't come cheap and is wired (not wireless)

Aug 19 2008 	Empark - Very Comfortable Amenities	I stayed at the Empark for the entire month of August while I was working at the Olympics. Upon arriving and through the entire stay, the staff was very attentive to my needs. The only issues I have is that the beds are extremely hard, free wireless is only available in the lobby - wired service is available in your room for a reasonable fee (hourly or by day) and laundry (which is done next door) is extremely expensive. Being in China I expected laundry service to be a lot cheaper than western hotels. In the basement of the hotel (floor B2) is a vegas-like mall. Restaurants, small boutiques, spas & a gym/pool that is free for VIP guests of the hotel. I swam a few times at the pool and worked out at the gym. Although the hotel claims the gym is open 24hrs, it isn't staffed round the clock and it often appears closed. The Golden Resources Cafeteria in the hotel is a decent restaurant that offers a buffet for breakfast and dinner. My stay included breakfast and I was never disappointed. They offer a good selection of cereals, juices and fruits, as well as an assortment of hot entrees, breads & sweet rolls. The coffee is good too! Taxis are fairly easy to come by at the hotel but keep in mind the hotel is located in the northwest part of the city and many of the historical attractions and shopping (Pearl & Silk Market) are on the southeast part of town - expect a long cab ride. Fortunately taxi fares are inexpensive here.If you're coming to town for sightseeing, I think you would find this hotel too far out of the way (Summer Palace is the closest attraction).

Aug 26 2007 	Great hotel...problematic communication	I stayed in Empark Grand Hotel for 4 nights (13-18/08), as I was participating in a conference held in the hotel.It was my first time staying in a 5 star hotel, so I was enthusiastic about the room and the hotel as a whole.It was very clean, quite impressive and well decorated. The food in the hotel's restaurant (lunch and breakfast) can be characterized as full. It had vegetarian menus, and seafood amongst others.The only problem I had was the communication part of my staying. The problem was that I was Greek, the reception manager was Chinese and we tryied to communicate in English, so we had to give much more effort than usual.In my lasta night there, I found out that there was a whole city underneath the hotel, but I didn't have time and courage to visit it.As a general, my staying there can be characterized as very pleasant. VagelisAthens, Greece

Jul 18 2005	Perfectly Good Hotel	Stayed here for five nights in the spring. A very comfortable hotel with all the amenities I needed. Helpful staff who speak good English. For about $100 per night US (including breakfast, which was satisfactory but not great), it's a very good deal. I guess there's a whole underground 'city' somewhere on the grounds, but I never got around to it. The rooms are quiet, comfortable, well-appointed, and if you're used to a 3-to-4 star place in the states, it will suit you fine. The beds are HARD AS A ROCK, but I found that to be the case everywhere else I went in China, too. Seems that's just how they do beds over there.The location could be a problem for some. It is in the Northwest of the city, not in a walkable part of town. A taxi to the city center (Tiananmen Square area) takes about 20-30 minutes in (always) bad traffic. But then again, cabs in Beijing are very cheap...It's about a $7 fare. Cabs are readily available at the front of the hotel 24/7. Or just take a taxi to a nearby subway (for half that price) and take the train (for something like 25 cents).

Nov 14 2009 	Good value for money in the center of Beijing	This hotel 20 minutes walk of Tienanmen Sq and 5 mins to metro station.100m to shopping mall with cafes and restaurants.Rooms are comfortable with all amenities including high speed internet (80Y per day).

Nov 13 2009 	A comfortable place to stay	I stayed at the Mercure Xidan for 5 nights in October 2009. I am an Accor member and at check in I was upgraded to an executive room. The room was good, everything worked, plenty of hot water, quiet, not much of a view but I wasn't in the room for the view.The hotel is ideally located - a 5 min walk to the Xidan subway and the large Xidan shopping complexes. Lots of shops, lots of food, KFC, McDonalds, Subway, the usual and all open till late.I used the subway every day - only 2 yuan to go anywhere! Plenty of self-serve ticket machines in Chinese/English.The 15-20 min walk to Tianamen Square is easy and enjoyable. I used the tour desk to organise a few train tickets for me - all done without fuss.A few of the staff spoke English better than others, but hey - this is China.

Nov 5 2009 	Good location nice staff rooms were WARM	I spent a week in the Xidan for a conference (also held in the hotel). Overall, my experience was quite good. The rooms are comfortable if not luxurious. The staff is very attentive, although the level of English varied from excellent to not-so-great. I could barely put out the "please make up my room" hanger before one of the cleaning staff would show up (within 10 minutes). Like many Beijing hotels, they warn you not to drink the water and to use the bottled water they provide. Some of my colleagues drank from the tap with no ill effect, but who knows. The hotel is in a great location for sightseeing, and I recommend renting a bike to get around to some of the nearby sites if you are willing to risk riding in the crazy traffic. My room came with complimentary breakfast buffet, which was really good and included comforting Western staples like eggs, bacon, and Frosted Flakes.I have two small quibbles: #1 It was WARM. Hot in the hotel room, and very hot in the basement conference rooms. The AC system seemed to be turned off. I spent most of the conference in a polo shirt becuase it was at least 80 degrees. My room was at least 78 or 80 degrees at night. I didn't sweat to death, but it was much warmer than I would have wanted -- and it was 60-70 degrees outside! The traffic noise was much too loud to open the window. #2 The internet service is verrrry slowwwwww. Fine for text e-mails but beyond that, prepare to wait and wait and eventually time out. It reminded me of the old days of dial-up access.

Oct 31 2009 	Close to many things..	First - a general warning in regards to most Beijing maps - look at the scale. Even the map the hotel provides made it seem like this hotel was a block away from Tianamen Square when it was a good 15-20 minute walk.This hotel was relatively cheap, and I think a good find in Beijing. It was West of Tianamen Square, a nice walk away or 2 subway stops. Two subway lines are within equal distance of the hotel, which is convinient to get almost anywhere in the city.This hotel is also close to the Pacific shopping mall, with many options for restaurants to eat at or places to shop for clothes.The property itself was nice - an elegant lobby with free wireless internet is there for you to use, along with comfortable seating. There was also a lobby bar that seemed popular with Westerners, though we never used it. The business centre provided reasonable prices to use the internet if you didn't have a computer for the free wireles.The front desk staff was friendly, and even included 2 caucasian's if you felt like you weren't communicating well with the local agents.Rooms were comfortable, but perhaps a bit in need of a renovation. I'm not sure how old the hotel or rooms are, but they could have used perhaps some nicer bedding and a bit of a refresh. The beds were comfortable and the bathroom was large and spacious. There was also a mini-bar in every room with items are good prices to purchase.With so much to do in the city we didn't spend long in the rooms. They were quiet for sleeping, despite the construction happening next door and we were able to keep it cool from the sun outside.I'd recommend this hotel for anyone staying in Beijing. It's probably not the most unique or memorable hotel, but it suited our needs just fine and with all the surrounding food choice, and close public transit, we were incredibly content with it.

Oct 5 2009 	Helpful	The 60th anniversary mandated curfew on this street where the hotel was. At our initiative, the hotel helped to move us away to Novotel Sanyuan without charge and even though our payment was non-refundable.Hotel staff were helpful and friendly. Room clean and tidy. Subway station of Xidan was near enough.

Sep 26 2009 	Great Hotel!	I stayed here for 3 nights from 15-18 September 2009, using the MasterCard - Accor Asia Summer Offer 2009 (One free night for every three nights). Average rate each night is CNY378.63 + CNY56.79 taxes.My flight arrived in Beijing at 6.35am and at 6.57am I took a taxi and reached Grand Mercure Hotel Xidan Beijing at 7.42am. Taxi fare is RMB91 plus toll RMB10.Avoid taxi during peak hours (7am-9am) & (5pm-7pm), the traffic is bad.The Hotel staff give us a earlier check-in after 2 1/2 hour wait at the lobby, there is free WIFI at the lobby.The Hotel is located along Xuanwumen Nei Main Street (??????).There are 2 subway stations within walking distance from the Hotel, they are - (Line 1) Xidan(??)station and (Line 2) Xuanwumen(???)station.

Sep 26 2009 	An ok hotel but nothing special	We stayed at the Mercure as it was part of a BA deal through Trailfinders. It was the best hotel on offer so we thought we'd give it a go.The hotel is fine - there's nothing really wrong with it - but it's just not anything special - especially if you've stayed at the Peninsular and Hilton Beijing Wangfujing.The room was very average - clean and comfortable - and although we were facing out onto the main road it was relatively quite.Breakfast was included in our booking and it edible but not really anything more than that. There were Asian specialities and some Western food but it was limited and the most disappointing thing was that most of the food was actually cold. This was the also the case when we tried the buffet one evening.The staff speak very limited English but were generally quite helpful and they definitely get a plus point for letting us check in at 10.30am after a long flight from London. They also get a plus point for their free internet and for the pool which was very nice.I know roughly what the rack rates are and I get the feeling it's slightly higher than it should be.

Sep 24 2009 	When in town stay here.	Earlier this month my wife and I took a short break to Beijing, 4 days 3 nights. During our stay in Beijing we stayed in the Grand Mercure Hotel Xidan Beijing. The hotel is 4* and lived up to its name with a warm atmosphere sumptuous rooms as well as one of the best breakfast choices we have come across in South East Asia.Before travelling we checked out travel reviews on two other hotels we were offered and decided not to tempt providence. The Grand Mercure was well spoken off and certainly lived up to the comments written in a positive way.The hotel is centrally located for shopping and reaching Tiananmen Square etc. We had the use of transport whilst there but the Metro is close at hand also.The hotel has a swimming pool; spa, sauna and fitness centre for use by hotel guests as well as massage services for a nominal fee.I would recommend this hotel to anyone visiting Beijing.

Sep 21 2009 	Very nice hotel near the Forbidden City	We stayed here four nights and found it a very nice hotel. The rooms were comfortable, clean and well appointed. Sep 17 2009	Taxi Trouble	We stayed here for 4 nights at the start of September. The hotel is conveniently situated with hutons and restaurants nearby, Times Square shopping mall next door, 2 subway stations and a short walk to Tiananmen Square. Breakfast was included and supplied a continental breakfast alongside a japanese one. The hotel had a pool and gym with a few CV machines and a multigym in the corner. Rooms were clean and staff were polite. The only trouble we had was getting back to the hotel! A number of times we tried with taxi drivers showing them the location on a map and even giving them the hotel card with the address written in Chinese however they pretended they didn't understand or couldn't read. Aug 31 2009 	Really bad hospitality	I would like to say something nice about this hotel. Because certainly it has some nice features. But bad customer service overshadows even the most praise-worthy amenities. So instead, I'm going to give what may seem like an unbalanced review of my four nights at the Grand Mercure Xidan, by noting what's wrong with this hotel, starting with my run-in with the health club staff. As some reviewers have noted before me, this hotel quizzically requires guests to bring ineffectual "bathing caps" in the pool. Most foreigners don't bring these Chinese accessories on vacation, but staff are more than happy to give you one at the desk...and add the cost to your room tab. I headed down to the pool with my 8-year old nephew on my first day at the hotel, was informed of the "bathing cap rule", and the kind girl at the desk lent me one of a handful of caps that she said were left over from other guests. I had explained to her that it didn't make sense to buy these caps for a few uses only. Problem solved. The next day at the pool we borrowed caps again. But on the third day, the desk was staffed by a guy who insisted that we buy one. Not only did he insist, but he did so in such a way that would make one question how he ever got a job in the hospitality industry. His behaviour was belittling and disdainful. He claimed I was lying when I told him that for the past few days I had been borrowing one, then he tried ignoring me hoping that I would go away, then he took on a really nasty tone. Not one to take treatment like that lightly (especially when I'm a paying guest), I called the duty manager, who patiently listened to my grievance, but in the end backed up the staff member (claiming that there were no used bathing caps available), and bafflingly offered me a fruit basket for my trouble(?!?!), proposing to examine the "swim cap" policy more thoroughly the next day. In the end, I conceded and bought the bathing cap - it was either that or not use the pool - but I was left with a very sour impression of the hotel. Every time my nephew and I used the pool after that, the desk guy glowered at us and couldn't even be cordial.Even before that encounter, the tendancy toward bad service had already been established at this hotel. On the second day, I asked the concierge how to get to the Temple of Heaven. After some confusion about what I was asking she brushed me off toward the bell boy who spoke virtually no English and directed me north instead of south. When I challenged him on it, he went and got someone else who gave me the correct directions to the south. Makes me wonder - if I can't get simple directions in English to one of the top 5 tourist attractions in Beijing, what good is the concierge?!?As for the amenities themselves, one of our first observations was the stench of the lobby washrooms. I can only surmise that it is a permanent problem because it didn't abate the whole four days we were there. Our room was uninspired - it overlooked a weed-infested inner courtyard that looks like it used to be a pool, and a building under construction next door. The tv remote control buttons were sticky and hard to operate. But worst of all was the closet-like bathroom - it was badly in need of some upkeep. The grout between the tiles was worn away, the toilet bowl had permanent stains, and every time I opened the bathroom door there was a bang from overhead (?!?) I chose this hotel based on positive reviews that I read here and because I am a loyalty member of the parent company. Yes there are some good things about this hotel, but I question how any of them matter in the face of such sub-standard treatment of guests. Needless to say, I will never be back and I recommend that you all give it a pass.

Aug 15 2009 	Everything we could have needed or asked for...	We stayed at the Mercure whilst enjoying Beijing on our honeymoon last month. Jul 21 2009 	An Oasis - great location service interior; yet few points of improvement	I stayed at the Grand Mercure Beijing Xidan hotel in July 2009, together with my girlfriend for 2 nights. We choose this hotel because of its location, 4-star rating and the deal we were able to get through a website. The GMBX is indeed located favorably. To the north is subway station Xidan (5 min walk) and to the south is station Xuanwumen (5 min walk). The bus stop is near the mall, about 8 minutes to the north of the hotel. Both stations are part of a different line which was very convenient for us since we wanted to explore the city and its attractions. The Forbidden Palace and Tiananmen is on walking distance (approx 20 min, head north-east), a great walk in the evening when the temperature has cooled down a bit. When you're up for it, you could walk from Wangfujing to the hotel, via the Tiananmen (about 30 min in total) Furthermore, since Xidan is a well developed area, you will find some business, parks and luxury stores near the hotel. A grand shopping mall is just north of Xidan station (approx 10 min walk from the hotel). Also you will find a Starbucks in the food court / luxury clothing mall in the building just outside the hotel. Finally, next to the hotel is a post office which also sells postcards. From the first sight of the hotel, we noticed that it handles French hotel standards, which is a good thing. The hotel itself can be called beautiful, at least from the inside. The lobby is amazing with fine pottery and glasswork, as well as a big aquarium and a big lounge with bar. From the outside the hotel looks ok, but by far not as neat as the inside. Since we arrived early, the staff offered us free drinks in the lounge so we had a chance to experience the comfort as well as the service. Holding our bags for a few hours was not a problem at all which gave us the oppertunity to explore the city. Staff spoke English very well, yet if you need to talk to someone about more complicated issues, ask for the manager (he is French). Anyway, the room we had had a double bed, desk tv, airco, minibar etc. All the things you are used to from 3/4 star hotel are there, including tooth brushes, shower gel, shampoo, towels, bath robes etc. The room was spacious, something we did not expect, and we even had a lounge chair with foot rest. We found the room clean and with two complimentary (daily) bottles of water, the start of our stay was relaxed. What we didnt like however was the bathroom. The shower seems to be somewhat dated, as well as the toilet which almost fell apart. We expected something more for a 4-star hotel so if there is something the GMBX could improve, its defintily the bathroom. Yet, we did not mind it that much since it was still clean and all. The view from our big window was not impressive since we could see the inner rooftop of the hotel. This seemed to be a former swimming pool or terrace. Now weed is growing all over it. This is perhaps the poorest part and most disappointing of the hotel in terms of interior and exterior. Coming back to our hotel after a busy day, felt like returning at an oasis. Refreshing yourself with a beverage and washing away the filth of the streets in our room. Also, our nights were very quiet and comfortable. Unfortunately I did not have the time to explore the indoor swimming pool and fitness center, but according to reviews on this website, they are very nice.As mentioned before, the service is that of a 4-star hotel. Bell desk is quick and fast, reception booked a table for us at a famous Chinese restaurant and even provided us direction for the taxi driver (not that we didnt take one, but its nice to have it).Probably another thing we liked was the breakfast. Its a Sino-European breakfast: you can find rice and noodles, dumplings and some dim sum here, combined with eggs (scrambled, benedict, cooked), sausages (hot/cold), cheese, fruit, juices, excellent coffee, various types of bread etc. Breakfast was seriously a great start of the day, something you really need when exploring this city.All in all we thoroughly enjoyed our stay at the GMBX, dispite the few flaws.

May 29 2009 	Good 4-Star Choice	I stayed at the Grand Mercure as a result of the reviews on Tripadvisor.com. That is simply not true. The Grand Mercure's rooms are spacious and clean, but they are definitely of 4-star quality. My carpet was tolerable but could use a good cleaning. The service was very friendly, but I also experienced some sub-par experiences such as: 1) It took them nearly 20 minutes to bring an iron and iron board 2) They forgot to replace my towels on one of the days 3) The cleaning lady insistently knocked on my door even when my "Do Not Disturb" sign was hung out (but she was very apologetic and friendly when that was pointed out to her).But like I said, for the price I paid (~RMB500 in May 2009) this hotel was a solid choice. And since you're a guest here, you are able to get those USD changed into yuan. (but can only changed it back in the airport)Security:The elevators needs key cards to be accessed and be used to go to the rooms.(although this is a good thing, a lot of us had a hard time in using our key cards)Each room has a security box. Even has an ethernet cable for your laptop. the beddings are smooth and clean. the pillows are really soft and are enjoyable when you sleep in them. The problem would be the washroom. (when i say hot it is scorching hot) A sauna is also found in the locker shower area. You would need to buy or have a hair cover/cap. (20 yuan for one overpriced if you ask me)The Fitness centerwasnt able to get in here but as far as i can see the equipments were up to date. Foodthe place has 3 places where you could dine. The lobby has a "bar" place where you could have drinks and even do a little internetthe 2nd floor has the V9 resto that serves buffet type food.(sad part about this is that it seems that their food is never changing) I have eaten breakfast here for 3-4 mornings and believe me, eating the same stuff definitely makes me puke at times. The 3rd floor has a chinese resto. Wasnt able to eat there but would be a nice experience i believeMy take:has nice location, service is superb, good place for a 4star hotel, would go back here but if i had more budget would definitely go to the newly refurbished marco polo hotel near the bird's nest.

Apr 22 2008	Good value	This must have been a very nice place when it was first built. Even the standard rooms are spacious, and contain some high end features, such as granite counter tops, bar, hair dryers.The general theme is minimalist cosmopolitan a little art deco-ish.It has however lost a little of it's lustre over the years. The hallways often smelly, and the carpets dirty. a few dents in the walls, peeling paint - that kind of thing. It is in the process of being renovated though, and the new lobby almost finished when we left.The room itself was clean where it counted. The bathrooms and the beds. Clean glasses and complimentary water.The service was excellent - we had our toilet plug (this happens easily in Beijing, be careful) and someone came and fixed it right away. Admin staff were plentiful and helpful - though not always fluent in English, they are patient while you charade your way through.The food was quite good, they have a French chef - and the buffet was a real variety. From lambchops to sushi. Also half price while we were there (about 10.00$ CAD)Catching cabs from the hotel was never a problem (with assistance from the doorman, but getting cabs to take us back to the hotel sometimes was. At first we thought they didn't know the location - but discovered that taxi drivers don't like to take fares the short distances that we often needed to go. Government taxis are incredibly cheap, so a ride from Forbidden city to Xidan (where the Mercure is located) only nets them about 2.50$ CAD. You can offer them a little more and they may take you. Or you can threaten to report them and refer to thier ID tag - as there is a heavy fine for them if they are caught refusing a fare.Also, good to know, some drivers know this hotel by it's previous name "The Marco Polo Hotel".All in all, I liked the hotel, slept like a log (nice and quiet) liked the location, liked the food, and the price (75.$ for a standard twin). I would certainly stay here again.

The biggest problem was actually getting a menu, as there wasn't one in the room - had to go down to reception and beg for one (nobody answered the phone when I tried calling from the room).As others have stated - most taxi drivers know this hotel as the Marco Polo. Even though one needs a taxi to get anywhere from anywhere in Beijing, I found that a lot of taxi drivers refused to take us to the hotel (ie from Silk Street), saying it was too far away. I noticed many other hotels that looked a lot more central and a lot nicer than this one - this has absolutely nothing to recommend it.Having said that - I can't really complain about anything specific. It was just OK. Beds were comfortable, room was large. But I wouldn't stay there again and would rather pick something newer and better located.

Oct 14 2007 	It's OK	We used the Grand Mercure as a base for a four night stay in Beijing. This certainly wasnt the worst hotel weve ever stayed in, but certainly not the best. Hotels in Beijing were quite expensive when we booked, so after much research and deliberation we opted for the Grand Mercure, Beijing. As some people have previously mentioned, this used to be called to Marco Polo, so if you are using a taxi from the airport (as we did) it might be worth telling the driver thats where youre going. First impressions werent bad, the bell hops took our luggage from the taxi and we proceeded to check in, however, when we went to our room, there was no bellhop, so we grabbed our bags our self and headed up. The lobby was clean and spacious with a bar at the back, small gift shop, concierge, tour operator and business centre. The room was large, but it was showing signs of wear and tear, however, it was clean. There were many reminders of the hotels previous identity - on the robes, towels, and drink coasters. I found this quite frankly to be a bit shoddy and lazy  these are very easy things to fix. Our room unfortunately overlooked a building site. We had paid for breakfast in the room rate, which by Chinese standards was very expensive. Whilst the breakfast was plentiful and featured a wide range of items, I think wed have been just as happy going Starbucks next door. On two of the four mornings we were questioned about whether we had paid for the breakfast in our rate, make sure your have two copies of your reservation, youll need one at check in, and keep hold of the second one just in case. The hotel has a swimming pool, sauna and steam room  be warned, you need to wear a swimming hat. We didnt find this area of the hotel very pleasant and actually didnt use the facilities.  My biggest disappointment with the hotel was with the tour operator. We booked a tour to see the Ming Tombs and Great Wall of China. DO NOT USE THE HOTELS TOUR COMPANY. We were picked up at the designated time of 7:30am, and didnt return back to the hotel until 7:45pm. We spent about one hour at the Ming Tombs and about one and a half hours at the Great Wall. The rest of the time was spent travelling, at a Jade factory, eating a pitiful lunch and at a silk factory. The tour was extremely expensive by Chinese standards. I would highly recommend you do some research before hand and make your own arrangements to visit these places. We were very disappointed with the tour, it was such a waste of precious time, and every where we went they were trying to sell us stuff. The tour company gets a kickback from the Jade factory and Silk factory, so its in their best interest to take you there. The hotel is conveniently located, you can easily walk to Tiananmen Square and there are plenty of shops around about. The subway is also located near by and is dirt cheap.

Aug 24 2007 	4 star hotel with 2 star ambience	We arrived to a room which smelled like staled rice crackers later to find it was the stench of mold. Our first room had black mold all over the shower and air conditioner. After a long night of trying to sleep, we asked to change our room. Our second room was a smoke filled room. One bed gave us some type of flea bites. The breakfast bufet was the least desirable. The staff were all new since the hotel was recently converted from the Marco Polo hotel. Registration took approximately 1 hour. The gift shop consisted of a closet without any postcards. Our tour guide said that this hotel was known as the second best 4 star hotel in Beijing . I think you if you are planning to visit Beijing you should try a 5 star hotel.Unhappy, US

Aug 22 2007 	Mis-represented as New Hotel !	Spent 5 nights at Grand Mercure Xidan earlier this month. While it is in a good location, close to metro stations, this is a largish hotel (around 400 rooms) that doesn't live up to the grand mercure chain reputation and leaves a lot to be desired. During my trip, we stayed at 4 locations - Nanjing, Beijing, Shanghai, and Xian - and this was by far the worst not only in terms of value for money but in every way!I stayed there with my 18y.o. son and we had a magazine promotional deal which said it was a "new" hotel.Well, it might have been new in the 1980s when it was built and known - as it still is to most taxidrivers - as The Marco Polo. But now it is a very tired spot in desperate need of a make-over. The rooms are not sound-proofed to the level we expect today - but in their favour they do have some inter-connecting family rooms, which are often hard to find. Even the bath-towels, mats and robes still bore the insignia of "Marco Polo" so it has evidently been a walk-in-walk-out takeover. The towels are threadbare; the bathmats unravelling. Yes, the bathroom is still serviceable and must have been very smart back in the early 80s as this is the style of fitting there, but overall this is NOT a quality hotel. The carpets are stained, the curtains are well past their use-by date and are no longer "block-out" by any standard, and the TV was one of the old clunkers with very few channels to select from! Lighting was dim and desperate, and we received minimal re-charge of our toiletries even though we were there for 5 full days. The bed linen was adequate, but not new, and the cupboards were de-laminating, though the safe appeared adequate. Our room on the 8th floor overlooked the festering rooftop above the restaurant several floors below, and featured overgrown "garden" and slush. Peering through the Beijing air pollution, we could barely see the opposite side of the large Avenue in front of us; however, this street view will be the better aspect as soon as the building that is currently being erected next door goes up a few more floors. Workmen are on it from crack of dawn, so a room with that view will be noisy as each successive floor is constructed! (They have constructed about 6 floors to date, so plenty more to go up! ) Given the very close proximity to Tianamen Square and major tourist areas, I can see the owners of this hotel have purchased for future position and not for current premises. I'd suggest it will be a future "tear-down" as are many buildings/hutongs in Beijing. There is a reasonably sized "Roman-style" swimming pool in the basement 3 levels below ground, and a spa that could take about 16 people, with a life-guard-cum-attendant who points at the signs (in English) and ensures one never steps out of line, though I woulnd't like to really need his life-saving skills - too close for comfort; one couldn't relax under his gaze. And they make you sign to buy their (too small) swimming caps before you are allowed into the pool! Use of the "business centre" is a joke. One ancient computer works slowly, with a keypad that jumps everywhere, and they overcharge you to use it! Breakfast was included in our promotional deal, and the buffet closes at 9:30a.m. SHARP. We weren't the only ones we saw caught out by this. Not that it is a good buffet; it offers an odd selection, trying to offer "American" style breakfast but not really making it, and very few fresh fruits or yoghurts suited to a light Australian diet. Quite a bit of Japanese-style items served, and a little cheese & crackers, and tired looking muffins & danish pastries. Take your own tea-bags if you want a decent cuppa! And don't expect much by way of service. The staff here are poorly trained and really need to practice their smiles (and uniform washing and wearing!) in time for the Olympics! The adjective "surly" comes to mind! Yet, given the rush to supply desperately needed tourist accommodation in time for next year's anticipated influx, I imagine the Grand Mercure Xidan will continue to get away with charging too much and giving too little. We were never given a map (we bought a very good fold-out laminated one at the foreign bookstore near the enormous shopping centre around the Hyatt Hotel)but only saw one on the last day when we needed to collect tickets from the concierge desk.  I'd chosen this hotel based on its proximity to sights as well as because of the promotion. Be aware that, given that taxis are cheap enough in Beijing and the scale of walking what might appear to be a few blocks is really quite a bit further than one might initially be lulled into thinking is a walkable distance, location of a hotel probably need not be your highest priority when selecting accommodation in Beijing. Because this is inner-city, it has the drawbacks that not many little restaurants are open after 8p.m., and certainly very few after 9:p.m. - we wanted something around then, and ended up with a walkable choice of KFC, McDonalds, Gloria Jeans, or a sushi-train type of place (we were their final customers at just before 10p.m. ) I think it would be as easy to be further out, use the Metro more - they are building new lines at a furious pace, and the trains are good, if very cramped at times (still not as bad as Tokyo) - and in a nicer hotel rather than stay at the Marco Polo/Grand Mercure. I certainly wouldn't choose it if visiting for the Olympics. There are closer, and what appear nicer, accommodations than this to spend my hard-earned dollars in.

Jul 16 2007 	Excellent value great hotel	We loved the Marco Polo! We stayed in December and good a real cheap deal (I think it was around 25 per night!). The hotel is modern, the rooms clean and comfy, the staff helpful and friendly. There is a travel desk in the main lobby, which can help you with trips and further travel arrangements (I needed to get a train ticket and they sorted that all out for me). Our room was large, the bathroom clean and medium sized. we even had HBO and a good buffet breakfast was included. It was excellent value for money! The location is good. Beijing has two main subway lines and there is a station for each within 500 meters of the hotel. There is also a large modern shopping centre close by. The Forbidden City is only a few subway stops from the hotel.

Jul 3 2007 	Great Value Great Location	The hotel was very nice overall for the price paid. Breakfast was plentiful with a nice variety of western and chinese dishes.The room we stayed in was large, clean and very nice. The room was a bit warm on the first night, though not really uncomfortably hot. I made a call to housekeeping in the morning and they fixed it by the time we got back in the afternoon. Jun 14 2007 	o.k. if the right deal	Got a good deal, in combination with the flights from uk so worth while, Make sure you get the address in chinese character and also Marco Polo (as many taxi's still know it as this..)Appears very out of the way on arrival, but it has very good subway connection 2 stops to Tian'amnen, you can walk to this but subway clean safe & very good, and runs late.Lots of modern Malls on doorstep of hotel(best part is there's no Westerns!). Starbucks 2 min walk (hotel coffee really awful). Mall next door has basement foodcourt many options for food (chinese/ japanese) and very good quality, clean/modern and cheap (aimed at young professionals). Other guests either chinese or european which makes for quieter environment.Summary: I'd stay again, as Mercure takes over from Marco Polo would imagine steady stream of improvements will be taking place. Hotel has pool and gym, but to be honest why use when so much to see! (appearred clean and modern)

Apr 18 2007 	Under new management	This hotel has now been taken over by Mercure and I am hoping they will make some necessary changes. Overall it was a good enough hotel in a convenient location, but there were some flaws. Our room (at the front) was far too hot and the aircon made no difference. Jan 28 2007 	A romantic winter	Enjoyed our free upgrade from superior room to suite when we check-in on Dec 23. A very romantic surprise for us! Staff at restaurant were friendly. Jan 20 2007 	Great time	Thought this Hotel was lovely. Oct 28 2006	Nice surprise	After reading other reviews I was apprehensive about the standard of this hotel but was ultimately pleasantly surprised. Oct 26 2006 	look elsewhere	When you step into the lobby it looks acceptable but it stops there.The rooms are dated and very worn, the towels were ragged and torn. The sheets and beds were scary. All the previous posts on the concierge are correct - they are of no help.As a bonus - they checked another guest into my room at 630AM in the morning by mistake, a nice Japanese gentleman barged into my room key in hand - needless to say it was the cherry on the sunday.I guess the only positive is that it forced me to stay away from the hotel - so i got to experience a good deal of the city.My advice - look elsewhere, please do it for me.

Sep 18 2006 	Hotel was average	My family booked 5 rooms at the hotel early this month for a tour in Beijing and I can say this hotel offers average amenities for a 4star hotel. Everything went okay, rooms were clean as expected, lobby was nice, staff were friendly and breakfast was good... except for the room air-conditioning that doesn't cool all night. I first thought it was only our room that had the problem but when we gathered for breakfast the next day, all our family members complained about their room airconditioning. We called the attention of the front desk and their answer was "since it's start of the autumn season and there's cooler air outside, their hotel decided to shut down the airconditioning"... according to the front desk, we will have to call housekeeping each night if we want the airconditioning turned on in our rooms. It's weird because we know for a fact that hotels shut their airconditioning system only during winter time and not during the end of summer or the start of autumn.Hotel location is average but I personally feel it would be best to be billeted in a hotel along the Wafujing Street especially if one's stay in Beijing is short.Overall stay in Beijing is good. The sights to visit are awesome! A must see on my list would be the Great Wall, the Forbidden City and the Temple of Heaven.

Aug 30 2006 	A nice place overalll	I stayed here in January and I find it to be a nice property. The beds were comfortable and the bathrooms a good size. It's hard to say if the location was good because everything in Beijing seems so spread out, however it was something like 3-4 blocks from Tiannemen Square. The staff were all friendly and most spoke good english or at least humoured my poor attempts at mandarin. The hotel is a very 'western' style hotel and seemed to cater to that market. Further down the road there was a very large shopping precinct with supermarkets, department stores and fast food outlets. The chinese love their fast food outlets and are great if you don't speak the language as you can point at the pictures to order. The only negative I had with this hotel was that you had to buy a swimming cap for about $10 to swim in the indoor pool. This was annoying but not enough to sour my stay.

Aug 5 2006 	So so	Location: not the best, wrong side of Tianammen SqRooms: we got upgraded, so happy with size, but decor outdatedStaff: nice, helpfulValue: you get what you pay forIf you can take the location, I recommend staying therePS: asked for a private tour to the wall WITHOUT any 'shopping' (i.e. jade factory tourist traps) stops - were made to stop anyway, so beware

May 31 2006	Great value friendly and conveniently located hotel	I booked the marco polo hotel using airline network and for 68 per room per night including breakfast it was by far the cheapest price. The hotel is 5 minutes walk from a Tube station and a shopping mall is also close by. Due to Beijing being so big and the sights so spread out we found being close to the tube extremely convenient and at appox 30p to use the tube a cheap option to get around. The reception is beautiful and all staff were very friendly and helpful even allowing us to leave our cases there for 2 days whilst travelling to Xian. On our first 2 nights stay we were upgraded to the continental suite which was on the 10th floor. The only real difference to standard rooms was a larger bathroom and shower cubical. The rooms were spacious with extremely confortable beds. You have a mini bar and free water along with all the usual free toiletries. The breakfast was lovely with a choice of fruit, breads, meats, cooked breakfast, cereals etc etc what you would expect from a 3-4 start hotel. My husband and I would certainly stay there again and would recommend it to our freinds and family.

May 23 2006 	Great stay for business travel	Got a great rate for the Corporate Floor from the Marco Polo's internet site. May 22 2006	competent hotel	Hotel is clean and quite well situated.No hotel meets all normal criteria for location in Beijing, and this one is fine for taxis to central sites, and for Summer Palaces. For Chaoyang (entertainment district= red light area in a very mild way) it's a bit of a hike. Things that ran out got replenished quickly.Staff language skills pretty good- outside staff would translate into Chinese for the driver, and the card was fine for getting you back to the hotel. Near two metro stations but we rarely used the metro, as 3 people meant a cab was the same price and didn't involve the ubiquitous stairs.Shop next door sold water, biscuit bars , beer at silly low prices.No restaurants of note nearby, although Times Square Plaza, about 3 mins walk away has Starbucks and a few decent fast-ish food places, including a Japanese, a Korean and "be There or Be Square"(Cantonese).Hotel restaurant OK- although the only one open is the buffet/ a la carte place. No in-house Cantonese at present. Foyer bar ok, usual high-ish prices.We took the Hutong tour from the hotel, and were very pleased. We went into a courtyard house, chatted via our guide with the owner over a tea, then visited a school. This is run by an outside organisation, but our concierge was genuinely interested in how we found the tour- and indeed on talking about the UK.

May 10 2006	Complete Mediocrity	After staying recently at the Marco Polo Hotel, I have to say that they have a long long long way to go before they can hope to host the crowds for the Olympics. In that sense, the hotel was a reflection of Beijing in general.Some objections:1. My requests for a nonsmoking room off the street were ignored (and no, Febreeze does not suddenly make a room NonSmoking).2. The level of English at the hotel was poor. I know that my Mandarin is nonexistent, but can the Concierge please speak English or German or French? Also, the Concierge seems to have no idea how to read a map or an address in Chinese!! My friend and I knew more about the layout of Beijing in 2 days than any of the Concierges did! We would show them the address in English and Mandarin, plus where it was on the map, and they still had to make phone calls to figure it out. Amazing. They also have no knowledge whatsoever of what is happening in town. We had to figure that out ourselves too. Thanks "Time Out Beijing"!3. The tour coordinator tries to swindle you into paying for extras that you do not want. For instance - I wanted to see the Great Wall - not a number of kitschy shops, tea rooms, etc. Beware. They practically kidnap you, as the guides they used are paid commission on your purchases at these cheesy locations. No thanks! We strenously objected, but the tour guide said we had to do what he said. Unbelievable. They will also try to charge you double or triple for the Opera. No need.4. We were charged a fortune for a pot of coffee in our room ($20usd). And when i pointed out that this must be an error, they were incredibly rude and refused to budge although they could not produce the receipt that I supposedly signed to agree to payment. My advice - either splurge for the really nice hotels like Grand Hyatt or go for a small, cheaper guest house in a Hutong. The Marco Polo was the worst of both worlds. No charm, No service.If you do stay there, be sure to rent a bicycle and ride away from the joint like the wind!

They gave me an oversized room with a perfect view of TianAnMen Square and the National Theater. The bathroom, however, was too small. Water pressure in the shower and the toilet was less than satisfactory. The 2nd time staying there, they put me in a really small room, which was a big disappointment especially for a return gurest. Because I arrived at 11:30pm, I was too tired to switch to another room. I had a cleaning lady knocking on my door and entered the room without permission. She didn't speak any English and was looking for something until another staff member came in to chase her away. Strange! The staff at the Continental level was very friendly and helpful. I stopped staying there since the price is fairly low and there were more and more local guests staying there with nonstop cigarette smoking and loud conversations. I really loved the decor and the class this hotel had. Unfortunately, the constant crowds of domestic and international tourist groups made this place much less attractive than before. Also, I've discovered the new Intercontinental Hotel, which is on the top of my list right now.

Apr 25 2006	Good enough	Stayed at the Marco Polo Beijing last week, and I guess I had high expectations. All in all the hotel was ok. Or maybe just take a cab.If you are going to be traveling by bus or cab all the time, then the location is fine.

Mar 27 2006	Great choice in this price category	At almost half the price of the luxury hotels in Beijing, the Marco Polo is a great choice for a clean and comfortable stay in Beijing. Though 5 stars may be a bit generous (4.5 was not an option), everything at the hotel was quite nice. Please note that there is some construction next to the hotel, but all of the guests I encountered on my stay were upgraded to jr suites or put on the west side of the hotel and did not have noise problems. But be prepared to take taxis nearly everywhere in Beijing no matter where you stay.

Jan 27 2006	Very Satisfied	I stayed here 3 nights in early November and was very satisfied. Make sure your room isn't on the side where there's construction going on. Oct 13 2005	Rate it 7 out of 10	The good: 1) Spacious rooms, nice linen, and the concierge will be quite keen to upgrade you if you are not happy with your room. All you need to do is politely complain, and they will come to your aid. We got a room facing an enormous construction site, and since they work 24/7 in Beijing, we decided to complain. We got a fancy suite facing the main street, which was quiet; the bathrooms are quite large with both a shower and a bath-tub (bath tub not reccomended though - black spots spitting out of the faucet and yellow water put us off a bit)2) People are bangig on about location in some of the reviews. I seriously don't understand the complaint. Mind you, Beijing is an enormous city, and ridicolously crowded, which in itself makes it a hard place for pedestrians; furthermore, taxi's are affluent and so cheap that it is hard to believe. We never paid more than about 2 USD almost anywhere we went, so in my world, it doesn't really matter where you are in this city, as long as you are somewhere inside the city, and not out by the airport or near a cest pit somewhere. Taxi is your key, and the easiest way to get around. Bring a map to show to cab drivers with names in Chinese - it will make everything a lot easier. 3) Staff was helpful, albeit language is an issue - but that was expected, so it didn't really matter.The bad:1) I mentioned all the construction in Bejing - which again leads to a lot of dust and dirt. The Chinese are also famous for their "spitting in the streets" habbit; I know a lot of guests wear their shoes inside; all this add to the icky feeling you get when you take your shoes off after a long day and stick your bare feet on a rather filthy rug.
