They tend to be a bit snippy and the are not attentive at all when food items run out, when you want more tea or honney and the like; 3 out of 5 days they were out of scrambled eggs and other things; all three times I had to ask them to sort some more out. No biggie, but three times over you start getting a bit annoyed, especially when the buff is expensive, and not that great.3) They brag about their indoor pool; it is OK but nothing fancy. What is worse, they force you to buy a swimming cap for 60 Juan before you are allowed to enter. A bit cheeky I thought, and it made everyone look ridiculous. One size does NOT fit all Europeans. But the pool was clean, which is good (it really should be in a 4 star so...).All in all: a good deal, and it is a great starting point for tours and trips to various sites outside and inside the city. If they got rid of their rugs and got wooden floors or similar instead, then it would be 5 star, and a much better, and more hygenic experience, for all guests. This will not bother brits - and Americans for that matter - since they seem to have the same nasty habbits with rugs as the Chinese - and many other countries for that matter, but for all Scandinavians who are accustomed to materials which makes it easy to dodge dirt and not collect it over time, the rugs at this hotel can be slightly off-putting. 1 point off for the breakfast staff, and two points off for filty, scrubby rugs: I give it 7 out of 10.

Oct 12 2005	Marco Polo? Marco Polo!	Just like Beijing's Panjiayuan Antique Market, this place delivers the "goods," at a deep discount relative to what you would pay in the U.S. or Europe. At $110 (U.S.) or 891 Chinese Yuan Renminbi per night (all charges and breakfast included) this hotel is a great deal. The rooms are modern with comfortable beds to ease your jet lag. The pool, fitness center, sauna, and steam room are blissful (see photos).Internet access is available from your room, there is a business center in the lobby, and most staff speak English. But it's the complimentary breakfast buffet, with all the Western and Chinese standards and a few extras (such as my favorite Swiss cereal) that really seals the deal. Located in Beijing's booming Xi Dan area, it's a short walk to the Xi Dan metro and its surrounding complex of high-end retail shops and restaurants. There's a 5-story underground mall connected to the metro, with a 3-D movie theatre and swimming pool/skating rink. The new Capital Times Square retail complex features luxury brand stores (with prices like in the U.S.) but also has an excellent food court (with prices much lower than in the U.S.). For example, a Dairy Queen Blizzard costs 90 cents. From the hotel, it's a short cab ride to many of the major sites, including The Forbidden City, Tiananmen Square, the Temple of Heaven, or the ritzy Wangfujing Street/Oriental Plaza/Grand Hyatt shopping area (all under $5 rides). If you take the subway, it's less than a dollar. The hotel concierge can arrange tours to The Great Wall or anywhere else. You can change money at the airport (keep receipt and you can convert it back upon departure) or at the hotel desk. A few tips: Although 100 Yuan is only about $12, you will be able to buy meals for much less than this, and even brand-name (e.g., Adidas, Diesel, and Lacoste) "knock-offs" or fakes for less than this at popular tourist markets like Ya Show and Hong Qiao Shichang. So, make sure you have some small Yuan bills because, on rare occasions, if you hand out 100 Yuan for a 20 Yuan cab ride, Buddha statue, etc., you might get some counterfeit bills in your change. While shopping, remember to start of by offering a third or even a quarter of the asking price. Haggling is generally expected (and encouraged) here! In fact, even in hotels, high-end stores, and airport shops, you'll see that you can often easily lower the price by asking for their "best price" or if you don't seem interested, they'll offer you the "discount price."

Oct 10 2005	New hotel in Beijing	My wife & I had a four nights stay in the new hoel in Beijing a few blocks west of Teinanmin Square.Very good location for touring all attractions in Beijing.Our corner room was large, quite, clean and comfortableWill stay there again next time.

Oct 6 2005	Lovely Boutique Hotel in the Middle of Smog City	We stayed at the Marco Polo for 8 nights and found it to be very good value due to an American Express special 3 nights for the price of 2 (each night was around US$105+15%). The hotel has an excellent location, situated between two subway stations on two different lines- this alone is almost worth the price of the room.We were upgraded to a room on the Executive Floor (rm1046) with a view of the construction site next door. The bathroom was beautiful- separate glass-enclosed shower, bathtub, marble detailing, great towels. The bed is very comfortable and furnished with feather quilt and pillows. TV has HBO, 3 news stations, ESPN and various Chinese channels.Staff are generally helpful and speak basic English (for excellent service and English, check for a chap called "Winter" at the Front Desk).A western breakfast buffet is served on the Executive Floor and drinks and cocktails are served at certain times throughout the day. Ok, now for the brickbats.-Although we LOVED the luxurious feel of the feather bedding, we had some problems with allergies and requested non-feather bedding. Our request was met with some limp pillows and ratty blankets.-The special rate of our room entitled us to breakfast for 1 person for the 8 nights we were staying. We negotiated with Winter at the Front Desk to divide the breakfasts between us (so, instead of 8 breakfasts for 1 person over 8 days, we would have 4 breakfasts for 2 people over 4 days)- we were very pleased with the arrangement however the next day after having breakfast, we were presented with a bill from the 'butler' on the 10th floor for one breakfast. She was very obstinate, had no idea about good customer service and told us (get this) that if we didn't pay, she would get Winter (the front desk clerk) to pay(!) so we had to get the manager in who cleared things up. This conflict played out throughout our stay, which made it a bit stressful during breakfast! By the way, breakfast really wasn't worth all the hassle- the usual hotel buffet spread, no Chinese options and TEA-BAGS! Can you believe it?!-We can't say for sure what happened, but my partner 'lost' US$20 from some money he had (unsuccessfully) hidden and I 'misplaced' some dried persimmons I'd brought from Singapore. OK, we should have used the safe for the money, but you'd think that some dried fruit would be safe from pilfering fingers?!-ROOM SERVICE FOOD IS AWFUL! One night, after doing 10KM hike on the Great Wall, we came back too late to dine at our favourite restaurant and ordered some Chinese items from the room service menu- quite possibly the most awful room service meal we've ever had the misfortune to digest. If you MUST eat in your room, try to get some dim sum from the third floor restaurant delivered to your room.-Concierge is a joke- direct all inquiries to Winter. -Access to quality newspapers is terrible- they have only one copy of the International Herald Tribune and The South China Post on the 10th Floor and they guard it jealously- no taking it back to the room to enjoy at your leisure!

Sep 22 2005	great except for location	Spacious room, drinkable tap water, helpful staff who spoke pretty good English. Dining room "okay," not great. Oddly, breakfast buffet cost more than either lunch or dinner buffet. Only big drawback was location. Not in walking distance of anything interesting. Only 2 restaurants nearby. One was very expensive and the other (across the street) double charged us for dinner.

Sep 9 2005	Fantastic Find	Stayed at the Marco Polo for 3 nights. Great rooms, lovely bathrooms and very attentive staff. Great location for T-square and Forbidden City. Can't say anything bad about it!

Sep 7 2005	A Marvelous Hotel at a Great Price	I just got back from four nights at the Marco Polo, as a result of the reviews on tripadvisor and the information in Frommers. I stayed on the Continental Floor for $110 a night for a double room including breakfast buffet (which was delicious).The Marco Polo is a beautiful hotel, with wonderful access to Beijing's subway system. The lobby will seduce you. The large room and marble bath were wonderful. The linens were of the highest quality. Amenities include slippers, bathrobes, umbrellas, late check out (until 4pm) along with the ordinary. The room was quiet and comfortable. They also have a large pool and very well equipped health club.The staff was great. They assisted me any number of times. It seems that the best price can be had on the hotels webpage.The only negative I could find is that the tours at the tour desk were overpriced. But isn't that always the case? You can arrange your own tours by using the advice in Frommers or almost any quidebook for half the price. Most of the comparable hotels were over $175 a night. The Marco Polo is a spectacular hotel and it's a steal.

Aug 16 2005	Great for business or please	Stayed at the Marco Polo for a week in May at the very end of a longer stay in China. Needed to get some work done while there, they had a great business center. They have a luxury business center on the top floor of the hotel. Rooms and bathrooms and very large and very luxurious. Look on line for a deal on the "continental club". Top floor rooms include use their the private library, large screen tv lounge, a great breakfeast buffet, and private discrete check-in. It was very VIP and comfortable. The location of the hotel was pretty good, on a nice day I walked to Tienammen and the Forbidden City. It was about a 20 minute walk. Also, while I was there they were finishing an opera house right across the street, should be ready soon. The conceirge was great, decent prices on tours (of course you can do better on the street) but by the end of my trip I was looking to fit in alot of things without any risk. Did their Great Wall tour, the Ming Tombs tour and the Peking Opera night. They negatiated cabs for us and recommended great places for all our needs. The resturant was pretty good, overpriced, but worth it for the convenience, same for the bar in the lobby.Highly Recommended

Aug 5 2005	Lovely oasis in the Big City	I stayed for five nights in the Marco Polo Beijing and really enjoyed coming back to my large, clean, comfy room after a day in Beijing's July heat. The staff was helpful and friendly, the room service food is quite good when you're just too tuckered to go back out, and the location is convenient: 15-20 minute walk to Tianenmen Square and very close to two metro stations.I'd recommend this for its quiet serenity and clean comfort.

Jul 28 2005	Excellent hotel	I stayed in the MP in July 2005 and found it to be an excellent hotel. The room was spacious, clean, and well-appointed. The mattress was a bit firm for my taste, but it wasn't uncomfortable. The location was good, a short walk to the Xidan subway station and shopping area. It's about a mile west of Tiananmen Square. Since a subway ticket is about 30 cents and taxis are quite cheap and efficient, location may or may not be a major factor, however. Service was very attentive and courteous. The facilities (pool, gym, jacuzzi, locker room, Cafe Marco) were very nice. I would stay in this hotel again.

Nov 26 2009 	Good locationclean	Stayed five nights as from 19th of October. Had a quite room on high floor . Enjoyed the good location (nearly walking distance to Tianmen square and Temple of Heaven) and good transportation point near Railway and subway! Enjoyed our stay. Recomended !

Nov 13 2009 	A bit dated but ok	Just across the road from the main railway station, I was able to check in at 8am following an overnight journey on the train from Shanghai. The Harmony is a little dated, however the room was a good size and very clean. There is kettle with tea, safe for valuables, mini bar and hte usual toileteries. However on the down side there was no bath (only shower), just one curious state run English TV channel, the air con didn't work and the bed was very hard. The foyer bar never seemed to be open and the one breakfast I had was poor, nothing left with an hour still to go - so get there early! Reception staff speak only a little English but enough to get by, they helped me hail a cab and explain to the driver where I needed to go. There's not much in the way of shops and restaurants in the immediate area, however the Oriental Plaza, the biggest shopping mall in Asia, is just a 10-15 minute walk away. And as you can imagine, you can find everything there!
